In Partnership WithCommand™ Brand

Courtney BalestierSenior Writer, Creative Studio

Courtney Balestier is the Apartment Therapy Creative Studio Senior Writer. She holds a master's degree in magazine journalism from NYU and lives in Pittsburgh, where you'll find her doing DIY projects in her new house with her dog and cat (who are not being very helpful).

published yesterday

If you have a small closet — aka a dorm room closet — you know that keeping all your clothes, shoes, and accessories organized is a constant challenge. Add in a few hurried mornings and some quick outfit changes between class and dinner with friends, and your closet can feel like an obstacle course of yoga leggings and going-out tops.

Ava LeBlanc, a student at Auburn University, wanted a design solution for her stuffed closet that would tidy things up and make getting dressed fun again. “My dorm room closet was packed to the brim,” she says. “I’d been meaning to organize this space for a while.”

She decided to add vertical storage, with wall-mounted hooks to keep her accessories in easy view (and off the floor). And because she used Command™ Brand Products, she could increase her closet’s storage space without damaging the walls or needing any tools.

First, Ava adhered Command™ Large Utility Hooks to one wall of her closet. Each of these substantial plastic hooks can hold up to five pounds, so they’re perfect for her purse collection. (Don’t forget to wait an hour after adhering before you hang anything on them!)

On another wall, Ava used Command™ Decorative Extra-Large Matte Black Triple Hooks to display her hats. These stylish hooks have a three-pronged design that holds up to 10 pounds, so there’s room for her storage needs to grow. And because all Command™ Brand Products remove easily without damaging walls, Ava can switch things up whenever she wants (without making her RA mad).

Now, getting dressed is once again Ava’s favorite part of the day. “This project solved my closet clutter problem and provided me a lot more space and organization,” she says. “It made walking in my closet and finding everything I need so much easier!”
